Why is this?
The vajra mind is the ultimate within the cause, and nirvana is the ultimate within the effect.
From the first thought onwards, all practices are causes for nirvana.
Although from the vajra stage onwards, it can also possess the meaning of cause and effect.
But without measuring the length of time since the arising of goodness, it is necessary to take the first thought as the cause, which can nourish the subsequent thought;
The arising of the subsequent thought of goodness must be due to the previous thought of goodness as the cause.
In this way, the continuity of the successive thoughts reaches the fruition of Buddhahood, which has the meaning of being both cause and effect.

If we take the latter thought and regard the former thought as the cause, and take the former thought and regard the latter thought as the effect, then the five practices are based on the cause, and the ten merits are based on the effect.
Now the ten merits further elaborate on the previous five practices.
